column3: :Definition_Short:
column4: :Definition_Long:

column3: Number of years the asset has already been in operation
Maximum permissable power at which the storage can be charged or discharged relative to the nominal capacity of the storage
column4: The C rate indicates the reciprocal of the time for which a battery of the specified capacity can be charged or discharged with the maximum charge or discharge current. A C-rate of 1 implies that the battery can be fully charged or discharged completely in a single timestep. A C-rate of 0.5 implies that the battery needs at least 2 timesteps to be fully charged or discharged.
column6: Real number between 0 and 1. Only the columns 'input power' and 'output power' require a value, in column 'storage capacity' c_rate should be set to NaN.

column3: Name of the country where the project is being deployed
Currency of the country where the project is implemented
Planning and development costs
column4: This could be planning and development costs which do not depend on the (optimized) capacities of the assets.

column3: Factor which accounts for the depreciation in the value of money in the future compared to the current value of the same money
column4: The common method is to calculate the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) and use it as the discount rate.

column3: Costs associated with a flow through/from the asset
column4: This could be fuel costs for fuel sources like biogas or oil or operational costs for thermal power plants which only occur when operating the plant.
column6: In 'storage_xx.csv' only the columns 'input power' and 'output power' require a value, in column 'storage capacity' dispatch_price should be set to NaN.

column3: Stands for Demand Side Management. Currently not implemented.
column6: Acceptable values are either True or False.

column3: Ratio of energy output to energy input
column4: The battery efficiency is the ratio of the energy taken out from the battery to the energy put into the battery. It means that it is not possible to retrieve as much energy as provided to the battery due to the discharge losses. The efficiency of the 'input power' and 'ouput power' columns should be set equal to the charge and discharge efficiencies respectively, while the 'storage capacity' efficiency should be equal to the storage's efficiency/ability to hold charge over time (`= 1 - self-discharge/decay`), which is usually in the range of 0.95 to 1 for electrical storages.

column3: Emissions per unit dispatch of an asset
Price of the energy carrier sourced from the utility grid
Energy commodity
column4: Convention: For an energy conversion asset define the commodity of the output. For a sink define the commodity based on the input flow. For a source define the commodity based on the output flow. For a storage, define the commodity based on the stored energy carrier.

column3: Number of days for which the simulation is to be run
Maximum capacity for feeding electricity into the grid
Price received for feeding electricity into the grid
Name of the csv file containing the input generation or demand timeseries
column6: This file must be placed in a folder named “time_series” inside your input folder.

column3: Thermal losses of the storage independent of the state of charge and independent of nominal storage capacity between two consecutive timesteps
Thermal losses of storage independent of state of charge between two consecutive timesteps relative to nominal storage capacity
Label of the bus/component from which the energyVector is arriving into the asset
Already existing installed capacity
column4: If the project lasts longer than its remaining lifetime, its replacement costs will be taken into account.
column6: Each component in the “energy production” category must have a value.

column3: Name of the asset
column6: Input the names in a computer friendly format, preferably with underscores instead of spaces, and avoiding special characters

column3: Latitude coordinate of the project's geographical location
Number of operational years of the asset until it has to be replaced
Longitude coordinate of the project's geographical location
Maximum amount of total emissions which are allowed in the optimized energy system
column6: Acceptable values are either a positive real number or None

column3: Maximum total capacity of an asset that can be installed at the project site
column4: This includes the already existing installed and the also the maximum additional capacity possible. An example would be that a roof can only carry 50 kWp PV (maximum capacity), whereas the installed capacity is already 10 kWp. The optimization would only be allowed to add 40 kWp PV at maximum.
column6: Acceptable values are either a positive real number or None

column3: Minimum degree of autonomy that needs to be met by the optimization
column4: This constraint defines a lower bound on the degree of autonomy of the energy system. Note that constraint is applied to the the whole, sector-coupled energy system, but not to specific sectors individually.

column3: Minimum share of energy supplied by renewable generation that needs to be met by the optimization
column4: This constraint defines a lower bound on the renewable share of the system, which takes into account both local generation as well as the renewable share of energy providers. Note that constraint is applied to the renewable share of the whole, sector-coupled energy system, but not to specific sectors individually.

column3: Specifies whether optimization needs to result into a net zero energy system (True) or not (False)
column4: BORDEL TU VAS FONCTIONNER
column6: Acceptable values are either True or False.

column3: Choose if capacity optimization should be performed for this asset.
column6: Permissible values are either True or False

column3: Label of bus/component towards which the energyVector is leaving from the asset
Enables the output of the linear programming (lp) file with the linear equation system describing the optimization problem
column4: The lp file contains the objective function and all constraints. It enables the user to look at the underlying equations of the optimization.
column6: Acceptable values are either True or False

column3: Grid fee to be paid based on the peak demand of a given period
Number of reference periods in one year for the peak demand pricing
column6: Only one of the following are acceptable values: 1 (yearly), 2, 3 ,4, 6, 12 (monthly)

column3: Number of years the project is intended to be operational
column4: The project duration also sets the installation time of the assets used in the simulation. After the project ends these assets are 'sold' and the refund is charged against the initial investment costs.

column3: Assign a project ID as per your preference.
column6: Cannot be the same as an already existing project

column3: Assign a project name as per your preference.
Share of renewables in the generation mix of the energy supplied by the DSO utility
Choose if this asset should be tagged as renewable.
column6: Acceptable values are either True or False

column3: Brief description of the scenario being simulated
column5: This scenario simulates a sector-coupled energy system

column3: Assign a scenario id as per your preference.
column6: Cannot be the same as an already existing scenario within the project

column3: Assign a scenario name as per your preference.
State of charge of the storage in the zeroth time step
column4: The state of charge is specified as a factor of the nominal capacity.
column5: :code:`storage capacity`: None, :code:`input power`: NaN, :code:`output power`: NaN
column6: Acceptable values are either None or the factor. Only the column :code:`storage capacity` requires a value, in column :code:`input power` and :code:`output power` :code:`soc_initial` should be set to NaN. The :code:`soc_initial` has to be within the [0,1] interval.

column3: Maximum permissible state of charge of the storage
column4: This is generally the case when the battery is filled to its nominal capacity, represented by the value 1. Users can also specify a certain value as a factor of the actual capacity.
column6: Only the column :code:`storage capacity` requires a value, in column :code:`input power` and :code:`output power` :code:`soc_max` should be set to NaN. The :code:`soc_max` has to be in the [0,1] interval.

column3: Minimum permissible state of charge of the storage
column6: Only the column :code:`storage capacity` requires a value, in column :code:`input power` and :code:`output power` :code:`soc_min` should be set to NaN. The soc_min has to be in the [0,1] interval.

column3: Specific investment costs of the asset related to the installed capacity
column4: CAPEX

column3: Specific operational and maintenance costs of the asset related to the installed capacity
column4: OPEX

column3: Date and time when the simulation starts with the first step. This date will be used for results graphs as well as timeseries upload, read more about timeseries upload here TBA (add a link here with following content: If the user upload a timeseries with timestamps, the start date will be used to only select the relevant values. For example the user can upload a timeseries of the entire year and then choose start date to be the 1st of June with 30 days of evaluated period, then only the month of June will be used from the timeseries. If the uploaded timeseries does not have timestamps, the first 30 values of the timeseries will be used instead. Uploading timeseries with timestamps allow for more flexibility of usage later on.)
column4: This date will be used for results graphs as well as timeseries upload, read more about timeseries upload here TBA (content of link: If the user upload a timeseries with timestamps, the start date will be used to only select the relevant values. For example the user can upload a timeseries of the entire year and then choose start date to be the 1st of June with 30 days of evaluated period, then only the month of June will be used from the timeseries. If the uploaded timeseries does not have timestamps, the first 30 values of the timeseries will be used instead. Uploading timeseries with timestamps allow for more flexibility of usage later on.)

column3: Name of a csv file containing the properties of a storage component
column6: Follows the convention of 'storage_xx.csv' where 'xx' is a number. This file must be placed in a folder named “csv_elements” inside your input folder.

column3: Tax factor
Length of the time steps
column6: Can only be 60 at the moment

column3: Type of the component
Input the type of OEMOF component
column4: A photovoltaic plant would be a source, a solar inverter would be a transformer, etc. The `type_oemof` will later on be determined through the EPA.
column6: *sink* or *source* or one of the other component classes of OEMOF.

column3: Unit associated with the capacity of the component
column5: Storage could have units like kW or kWh, transformer station could have kVA, and so on.

column3: Power loss index for CHPs, usually known as beta coefficient
